DataElement.preferredDefinition: A response used to determine the anticipated outcome that was intended or that guided the delivery of a treatment plan that was previously administered.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Earlier in time or order._An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process._An anticipated outcome that is the purpose for actions taken, thus guiding the action.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Earlier in time or order.:An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

Concepts.definition: Earlier in time or order.
An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.

Property.preferredDefinition: Intent; an anticipated outcome that is intended or that guides your planned actions.

Concepts.definition: An anticipated outcome that is the purpose for actions taken, thus guiding the action.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Text description of the anticipated outcome or intent of a treatment regimen/program._Intent; an anticipated outcome that is intended or that guides your planned actions._Category; used informally to mean a class of things._An action or ministration that produces an effect or that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having no signs or symptoms of disease.: (MET-uh-STAT-ik) Having to do with metastasis, which is the spread of cancer from one part of the body to another.

Concepts.definition: Without clinical signs or indications that raise the possibility of a particular disorder or dysfunction.
A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Palliative care is the patient-and family-centered active holistic care of patients with advanced, progressive disease. Traditional models reflect abandonment of proactive treatment and a simultaneous increase in symptom control and comfort-related services, as a disease progressed in linear fashion through its course. Essential components of palliative care are: pain and symptom control, communication regarding treatment and alternatives, prognosis, and available services, rehabilitation services, care that addresses treatment and palliative concerns, intellectual, emotional, social, and spiritual needs, terminal care, support in bereavement. The goal of palliative care is an achievement of the best quality of life for patients and their families.

Concepts.definition: The patient- and family-centered active holistic care of patients with advanced, progressive disease. Essential components of palliative care are: pain and symptom control, communication regarding treatment and alternatives, prognosis, and available services, rehabilitation services, care that addresses treatment and palliative concerns, intellectual, emotional, social, and spiritual needs, terminal care, support in bereavement. The goal of palliative care is an achievement of the best quality of life for patients and their families.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An agent that enhances the activity or therapeutic effect of another pharmacologic substance without having much, if any, therapeutic impact by itself.

Concepts.definition: An agent that enhances the activity or therapeutic effect of another pharmacologic substance without having much, if any, therapeutic impact by itself.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Serving or tending to restore health; a remedy.

Concepts.definition: Serving or tending to restore health; a remedy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An indication that a person has a condition or disease.  Some examples of symptoms are headache, fever, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and pain.: The act of directing or determining; regulation or maintenance of a function or action; a relation of constraint of one entity (thing or person or group) by another.

Concepts.definition: Subjective evidence of disease perceived by the patient.
The act of directing or determining; regulation or maintenance of a function or action; a relation of constraint of one entity (thing or person or group) by another.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.: An indication or description that a particular disorder is being managed successfully.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.
An indication or description that a particular disorder is being managed successfully.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Treatment given as a first step to shrink a tumor before the main treatment, which is usually surgery, is given. Examples of neoadjuvant therapy include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. It is a type of induction therapy.

Concepts.definition: Therapy administered prior to the primary treatment for the purpose of making the primary treatment more effective.
Evidence of preventive.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of a drug that makes tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.

Concepts.definition: The use of a drug that makes tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having to do with symptoms, which are signs of a condition or disease.: (MET-uh-STAT-ik) Having to do with metastasis, which is the spread of cancer from one part of the body to another.

Concepts.definition: Exhibiting the symptoms of a particular disease.
A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Treatment that is given after the cancer has not responded to other treatments.

Concepts.definition: Performing a salvage procedure is the last resort. The clinical situation involves either ongoing life support measures, life support measures for more than 60 seconds during the prior 10 minutes, or unanticipated institution of extracorporeal circulatory support. (ACC)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The return of signs and symptoms of cancer after a period of improvement.

Concepts.definition: The return of signs and symptoms of cancer after a period of improvement.
